awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SC2: A Systems Approach to Spectrum Collaboration
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless spectrum is a precious resource that can only be meaningfully used when access is controlled. Current mechanisms for control are largely legislative, granting organizations and individuals the right to exclude others. Exclusive use of frequency ranges over time and space can be highly inefficient - denying non-interfering, would-be users access despite under-utilization by rights holders. Spectrum collaboration is advanced as an alternative control mechanism in which intelligence on the part of transceiver equipment is used to simultaneously govern access and maximize utilization. Such intelligence is manifested in the form of sophisticated algorithms and supporting flexible radio and computing hardware. This proposal takes a systems approach to spectrum collaboration. The PIs propose new approaches to understand and classify activities within a range of frequencies and to study and evolve channel access protocols that are both proactive (getting data through) and polite (assisting others in the mission of getting their data through). More broadly, the investigators seek to create novel protocols and tools to facilitate spectrum sharing.

The proposed research is built on three pillars: (a) improved spectrum sharing through PHY-layer optimization techniques such as beamforming and interference cancellation, (b) mechanisms to learn the RF environment and spectrum usage patterns using reinforcement learning and signal classification, and (c) defining a model for spectrum sharing, called channel-as-society (CAS). The investigators contend that advances in these three domains have direct applicability to the practice of spectrum collaboration and the DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge (SC2) in particular. The investigators' ongoing joint work on Low-Power Wide-Area Networking (LP-WAN) serves as a testbed for some of the concepts relevant to SC2, both informing and being informed by the proposed research. In addition, the investigators plan to co-teach a Special Topics course in Wireless Networks and Mobile Computing specifically targeting the SC2 problem statement, engaging the students in the creation of novel SC2 concepts and techniques.

por.por_cntn:
The investigators assembled a team of researchers to participate in the DARPA Spectrum Collaboration Challenge (SC2) with the objectives of (a) seeking new approaches to understand and classify activities within a range of frequencies and to study and evolve channel access protocols that are both proactive (getting data through) and polite (assisting others in the mission of getting their data through); and (b) seeking to create, in the open and among other Spectrum Collaboration Challenge (SC2) participants, novel protocols and tools to facilitate spectrum sharing. 

We designed an OFDMA based strategy for the SC2 competition, where each node in the network would choose a particular set of subcarriers unique to that node. This ensured that there would not be any self-interference, with the downside of having no way to dynamically allocate bandwidth. If channel conditions proved difficult, the nodes could choose to switch to a half-rate convolutional code to improve the probability of successful transmission. On a clean 20MHz channel, this implementaiton was able to transfer a total of 8Mbps over four continuous links, 2Mbps per link. Our efforts led team CMU to qualify for next year's competition. 

We developed a software-radio based replica on the CMU campus of the DARPA Colosseum, which we dubbed ``Mini-Colosseum.'' The Mini-Colosseum testbed continues to be a valuable platform for students in related courses to quickly test and validate code on a real radio but without outside interference. The mini-Colosseum played an important role as a pedagogical tool in the PIs' wireless courses for students to implement and evaluate their projects.

The research and testbeds used for SC2 has broadly been used by the PIs in research outside of SC2, such as our work in the space of Low-Power Wide-Area Networks (LP-WANs). The PIs' recent work on cloud-based joint-decoding in LP-WANs from software radio frontends was recently awarded the best paper award at ACM/IEEE IPSN 2018 at Porto, Portugal held as part of CPS-Week. 

 

PI Kumar developed a new graduate course at Carnegie Mellon targeting the DARPA SC2 challenge: Wireless Networks and Mobile Systems - SC2 Edition (18-859G) in Fall 2017. The class had a series of lectures on state-of-the-art research in wireless networks and machine learning, with special emphasis on spectrum sensing. The class had a course-long project where teams of two developed modules for the SC2 challenge, including at the PHY, spectrum sharing solutions at the MAC and machine learning solutions for better spectrum access.  

co-PI Iannucci introduced spectrum collaboration concepts and techniques to his Fall 2017 MS-level class 18-747 Wireless Device Architecture.  Two student teams took up the challenge of using machine learning techniques to sense and interpret spectrum information. This task was divided into two components---the first team developed a prototype system for identification of individual transmitters in a channel using detection algorithms borrowed from computer vision. The second team focused their efforts on modeling temporal behavioral of multiple transmitters using recurrent neural network techniques.
